history.content:
The message you and all students received from the Chancellor included the following:

"Students will not be required to take in-person classes or be present on campus for the smaller discussion sections. Almost all academic offerings, including those with in-person instructional activities, will also be provided via a remotely delivered method."

There isn't as far as I know any plan for every class to report out specific plans at any particular time (except of course it would be part of the syllabus that would be available by the first day of class).  While I can't promise that there will not be a very small # of classes that might not be possible to be taught at a distance nor can I promise that none of the classes will be cancelled, there are currently any plans to do so that I have heard.

children.subject: Good catch. Then that's what will happen.

<md>> There isn't as far as I know any plan for every class to report out specific plans at any particular time

https://sa.berkeley.edu/covid19/Fall2020#1

According to this don't all the classes have to report by end of July which and how the classes are being offered in person?</md>

history.content:
It looks like the official announcement is out that Fall will be "hybrid." But since CS classes tend to be quite large, but also have smaller discussion sections, does the EECS department have official plans on how this will play out? I saw the announcement for 161 but what about guidelines for other classes? I personally hope that students can have the option to be remote if they want to, because I don't want to have to do housing on campus if I'm going to be afraid of doing social activities. 

Also, does EECS department have a timeline for when classes will officially be announcing plans? It's quite time sensitive for me since it may determine if I actually need to find housing this fall.

And finally, does this have ramifications on whether or not some classes like 160 will either be cancelled since in-person interaction is such a big part of it, or if it will actually expand since it'll be online?
history.subject: EECS classes remote?
